Abstract: Photosystem II (PSII) is a critical component of the photosynthetic machinery, responsible for the light-driven oxidation of water, a process essential for the production of molecular oxygen and the sustenance of aerobic life on Earth. This review explores the evolutionary history and evolvability of PSII, tracing its origins back to ancient cyanobacteria and the emergence of oxygenic photosynthesis. The D1 protein, a core subunit of PSII, plays a pivotal role in the water-splitting complex and has been a focal point for understanding the molecular adaptations that have enabled PSII to function efficiently under diverse environmental conditions. Recent studies have shed light on the structural and functional dynamics of PSII, revealing the intricate mechanisms that have allowed this complex to evolve and adapt over billions of years. This knowledge not only enhances our understanding of the origin of life but also provides insights into the potential for engineering more robust and efficient photosynthetic systems.
